title: What makes someone vote against their political party? - Sarah Longwell

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people's desire for community and belonging can lead to tribal instincts?
What did Sarah Longwell's team use to help create a new tribe called "Republican Voters Against Trump"?
Why do voters not talk about democracy in the same way that politicians do?
What is the main reason why winning elections by building a dominant political coalition using permission structures and trusted messengers can help us tell a better story about democracy?
What is the main message of Sarah Longwell's talk?
What is the main reason why the fact that voters don't think much about democracy is actually our greatest opportunity?
What is the main conclusion of Sarah Longwell's talk?
What is the main reason why we need to win elections by building a dominant political coalition using permission structures and trusted messengers?
What is the main reason why the big tribe that is America is strong enough to hold all the other little tribes inside of it?
What is the main reason why we need to talk about democracy better and explain to people what democracy is and why it's good?

title: How can groups make good decisions? - Mariano Sigman and Dan Ariely

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video?
What is the name of the colleague with whom the speaker conducted experiments?
What is the "robust average" that groups use to reach consensus?
What is the main trend that emerges from the moral dilemmas presented in the video?
What is the main idea of the conclusion of the video?
